abstract: Patterson-UTI Energy, which provides drilling services to oil and natural gas exploration companies, acquires 17 land-drilling rigs from Cleere Drilling Co for at least $23.4 million in cash and stock (S)
snippet: Patterson-UTI Energy, which provides drilling services to oil and natural gas exploration companies, acquires 17 land-drilling rigs from Cleere Drilling Co for at least $23.4 million in cash and stock (S)
lead_paragraph: Patterson-UTI Energy, which provides drilling services to oil and natural gas exploration companies, has acquired 17 land-drilling rigs from the Cleere Drilling Company for at least $23.4 million in cash and stock. The price includes $13.5 million in cash, 450,000 shares of Patterson-UTI common stock and 325,000 warrants convertible into common shares at a price of $26.75, Patterson-UTI said. The common stock portion is valued at $9.9 million based on Monday's closing price. The acquisition is the first since Patterson Energy completed its $1.1 billion buyout of the UTI Energy Corporation in May. The purchase from the closely held Cleere gives Patterson-UTI, based in Snyder, Tex., 319 rigs. Cleere Drilling is based in San Angelo, Tex.

lead_paragraph: Magnum Hunter Resources Inc., which has more than 3,000 oil and natural gas wells in the South and Southwest, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival, the Prize Energy Corporation, for $300 million in stock and cash. After the acquisition, Magnum Hunter shareholders would own 51 percent of the combined company and Prize Energy shareholders would own the remainder, the companies said. Prize Energy's shareholders will get $24 for each of their shares, which rose $4.41, or 24 percent, to $22.51. Magnum Hunter shares fell 51 cents, or 6.1 percent, to $7.79.

abstract: Houston couldn't stop itself from overreaching, and Houston wouldn't be able to stop itself from crashing again, either.
snippet: Houston couldn't stop itself from overreaching, and Houston wouldn't be able to stop itself from crashing again, either.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON -- I saw Continental's chief executive, Gordon Bethune, give a speech the other day, and I was happy to see he had his game face on. His slicked-back silver hair shimmered; the charcoal suit that squared his shoulders was a thing of beauty. Mr. Bethune's Houston-based airline may be fighting for its life, but he was confidently witty and profane, with a bounce to his step that was nearly convincing.

abstract: Lone Star Technologies Inc says it is unable to find financing for its $430 million purchase of Cargill division that makes steel tubes used to drill for oil (S)
snippet: Lone Star Technologies Inc says it is unable to find financing for its $430 million purchase of Cargill division that makes steel tubes used to drill for oil (S)
lead_paragraph: Lone Star Technologies Inc., a maker of pipe used in oil and gas drilling, said it had not been able to arrange financing for a $430 million purchase of the steel-tube-making unit of Cargill Inc. Investors are reluctant to buy the bonds and new stock that Lone Star planned to issue to finance the purchase because of falling demand for the company's seamless pipes among drillers, analysts said. Interest rates on some types of high-yield debt have soared 40 percent since the deal was announced four months ago, driving up financing costs. Cargill has filed a lawsuit charging Lone Star with breaching their agreement and seeking unspecified damages, said Greg Lauser, a spokesman for Cargill, which is based in Wayzata, Minn. Lone Star officials did not return calls seeking comment.

abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Saudi Refining Inc will buy ChevronTexaco Corp's interest in two refining ventures for $3.86 billion (S)
snippet: Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Saudi Refining Inc will buy ChevronTexaco Corp's interest in two refining ventures for $3.86 billion (S)
lead_paragraph: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Saudi Refining Inc. have agreed to buy the stakes of the ChevronTexaco Corporation in two refining ventures for $3.86 billion. The companies will pay $2.26 billion in cash to the Texaco Alliance Trust and assume about $1.6 billion in debt, the trust said. ChevronTexaco put its stakes into the trust in October as part of a settlement with regulators that allowed Chevron to buy Texaco. Under the deals, the Shell Oil Company, the American unit of the British-Dutch company, will own all of the Equilon Enterprises venture it had owned with Texaco. Shell and Saudi Refining will each own 50 percent of Motiva Enterprises, which had been 35 percent owned by Texaco. The sale, which requires approval from federal regulators, is expected to close in mid-January.

abstract: Norway will decide by Christmas how much oil to trim from its production; indicates that cut will be about 150,000 barrels a day (S)
snippet: Norway will decide by Christmas how much oil to trim from its production; indicates that cut will be about 150,000 barrels a day (S)
lead_paragraph: Norway's oil minister said the country would decide by Christmas how much oil to trim from its production, but indicated that the cut would be about 150,000 barrels a day, Reuters reported. Oil output cuts from Norway, the largest exporter after Russia outside OPEC, would probably satisfy the cartel, which had insisted on cuts of 500,000 barrels from all nonmembers before trimming 1.5 million barrels of its output early next year. The secretary-general of OPEC, Ali Rodriguez, said in London that the cartel is ready for a deal ''in principle,'' but is still waiting for other countries, like Norway, to decide on pledges. Russia said yesterday that it would trim exports by 150,000 barrels a day. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

abstract: Shares of PTT, Thai oil and natural gas company, rise 2.2 percent on first day of trading on Stock Exchange of Thailand, demonstrating overseas investors' surprising interest in stock (S)
snippet: Shares of PTT, Thai oil and natural gas company, rise 2.2 percent on first day of trading on Stock Exchange of Thailand, demonstrating overseas investors' surprising interest in stock (S)
lead_paragraph: Shares of the Thai oil and natural gas company PTT rose 2.2 percent in their first day of trading on the Stock Exchange of Thailand. Thailand's government sold one-third of the company last month for 32.2 billion baht ($733 million), making rare progress in its plan to privatize public companies and fill a government budget deficit. Overseas investors demonstrated a surprising interest in the shares, which appeared to signal a newfound taste for emerging-market assets. Analysts said foreign funds continued to pour into Southeast Asia this week, but that investors had shifted their purchasing to technology stocks that could benefit from indications of a rebound in the semiconductor industry. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

abstract: Economists say Alaska, which relies on oil and gas revenue for about 80 percent of its general fund, will run out of budget reserves in July 2004 unless oil prices rise sharply (S)
snippet: Economists say Alaska, which relies on oil and gas revenue for about 80 percent of its general fund, will run out of budget reserves in July 2004 unless oil prices rise sharply (S)
lead_paragraph: Unless oil prices rise sharply, the state's $2.4 billion in savings will run dry in July 2004, economists said. After two years of high prices, oil leveled off this year at $18 a barrel, widening a fiscal gap that will require the state to draw 40 percent, or about $1 billion, of the annual budget from its budget reserve fund. The state has no sales or income tax, so about 80 percent of its general fund comes from oil and gas revenue, and production has been declining at Prudhoe Bay, Alaska's largest source of oil. Since 1991, the state has had to dip into its reserves all but two years. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

lead_paragraph: * Castrol Worldwide, part of BP, London, consolidated the worldwide creative account for its lubricant brands like Castrol, GTX and Syntec by naming offices of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, to handle that assignment. Spending was estimated at $120 million. Ogilvy is also the worldwide creative agency for BP. The creative account of Castrol North America, with spending estimated at $40 million, will be moved to Ogilvy from Hampel/Stefanides, New York, part of the Envoy Communications Group, which had handled that assignment since 1993.

abstract: Editorial says Russia could help encourage trend toward warmer ties with US by refusing to go along with oil production cuts that OPEC favors
snippet: Editorial says Russia could help encourage trend toward warmer ties with US by refusing to go along with oil production cuts that OPEC favors
lead_paragraph: Russia may no longer be a military superpower, but in recent years it has quietly become a behemoth in the oil business, a development with important political and economic implications for the United States and its allies. Moscow is now in a position to sharply limit the ability of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to manipulate oil prices. By refusing to go along with production cuts that OPEC favors, Russia can enhance its reputation as a responsible and reliable supplier of Europe's energy needs. That is an opportunity President Vladimir Putin should not squander.

abstract: Niall Ferguson article says that attacks on Pentagon and World Trade Center are far less of turning point in history than is generally believed and that world 10 years from now is being shaped by historical trends that were well under way before Sept 11: globalization of terrorism, economic downturn and approach of second energy crisis, transition of American global power from informal to formal imperialism and process of political disintegration as religious and ethnic conflicts challenge integrity of existing multicultural nation-states; drawing (L)
snippet: Niall Ferguson article says that attacks on Pentagon and World Trade Center are far less of turning point in history than is generally believed and that world 10 years from now is being shaped by historical trends that were well under way before S...
lead_paragraph: Take the long view. What will New York be like on Sept. 11, 2011? It's not difficult to imagine a rather wretched future. You need only visit one of those cities -- Jerusalem or Belfast -- that have been fractured by terrorism and religious strife to get a glimpse. Imagine a segregated city, with a kind of Muslim ghetto in an outer borough that non-Muslims can enter only -- if they dare -- with a special endorsement on their ID cards. Imagine security checkpoints at every tunnel and bridge leading into Manhattan, where armed antiterrorist troops check every vehicle for traces of explosives and prohibited toxins.

abstract: Russia advances oil pipeline project to ship its crude directly to Western European markets through Croatian pipeline system to Adriatic Sea port of Omisalj; Croatia agrees to guarantee shipment (S)
snippet: Russia advances oil pipeline project to ship its crude directly to Western European markets through Croatian pipeline system to Adriatic Sea port of Omisalj; Croatia agrees to guarantee shipment (S)
lead_paragraph: Russia advanced an oil pipeline project to ship Russian crude directly to Western European markets; the oil will go through the Croatian pipeline system to that country's Adriatic Sea port of Omisalj. In a meeting with Croatian officials, the Russian energy minister, Igor Yusufov, agreed to guarantee shipments of Russian crude for the pipeline and to hold talks with other participating countries. Under the project, pipeline and storage equipment would be upgraded to ship 100,000 barrels of oil a day from Russia's main oil artery into Central Europe to the Croatian oil terminal by 2003. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column discusses economic and political ramifications of oil price cycles, noting that it is likely that today's oil price plunge will set stage for tomorrow's oil-price surge (M)
snippet: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column discusses economic and political ramifications of oil price cycles, noting that it is likely that today's oil price plunge will set stage for tomorrow's oil-price surge (M)
lead_paragraph: The price of crude oil, which was around $30 per barrel earlier this year, plunged last week to as little as $17, with warnings that it could go still lower. Alas, it's all too likely that today's oil price plunge will set the stage for tomorrow's oil price surge, in a repeat of a cycle that has been a major source of world instability these past three decades. Intelligent policies could break this cycle, but our actual policies seem, if anything, likely to make the cycle worse.

abstract: Kaneb Pipe Line Partners agrees to buy terminals in Canada and Netherlands Antilles from Statia Terminals Group for $193 million; will also assume $107 million in debt (S)

lead_paragraph: Kaneb Pipe Line Partners, a fuel transporter, agreed to buy terminals in Canada and the Netherlands Antilles from the Statia Terminals Group for $193 million. Kaneb will also assume $107 million in debt for the terminals, which make up almost all of Statia's assets, the company said. The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter. The company will get a terminal in St. Eustatius, east of Puerto Rico, and one in Point Tupper, Nova Scotia. The deal will increase terminal capacity by about 42 percent, to 63.1 million barrels.

abstract: CONNECTICUTMERIDEN: SHOOTING LEAVES ONE DEAD AND 2 INJURED The police yesterday said they were following leads in a possibly random triple shooting that killed one man and injured two others. The dead man, Derling Mercado, 22, of Meriden, was shot twice in the back and died early Sunday outside his home, the police said. Carlos Figueroa, 25, of Meriden, was wounded in the stomach and Ezequiel Rivera, 17, of West Haven, was shot in the leg. Mr. Figueroa was in stable condition Monday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. Mr. Rivera was in fair condition at the Hospital of St. Raphael in New Haven.   (AP).

abstract: In This Particular Tire Test, Failure Was Not an Option  To hear Edouard Michelin tell it, there was almost a
snippet: In This Particular Tire Test, Failure Was Not an Option  To hear Edouard Michelin tell it, there was almost a
lead_paragraph: To hear Edouard Michelin tell it, there was almost a "religious silence" when the Air France Concorde took off from Charles de Gaulle airport at 10:30 a.m. on Wednesday. With the plane safely airborne, the passengers broke into the kind of applause that travel sophisticates usually eschew. Small wonder: the supersonic jets were grounded after July 25, 2000, when a blown tire on takeoff caused a fatal crash, so even road warriors could be forgiven a small frisson. Mr. Michelin, though, insists that the applause came less from relief than delight. "Everyone was just so happy that this big white magic bird was back in the air," he said.

abstract: USX-Marathon agrees to buy CMS Energy's stakes in oil and natural-gas fields in Equatorial Guinea for $993 million in cash (S)
snippet: USX-Marathon agrees to buy CMS Energy's stakes in oil and natural-gas fields in Equatorial Guinea for $993 million in cash (S)
lead_paragraph: The oil company USX-Marathon said yesterday that it had agreed to buy CMS Energy's stakes in oil and natural-gas fields and methanol and gas-processing plants in West Africa's Equatorial Guinea for $993 million in cash. Marathon, which is based in Houston, will get the equivalent of 250 million barrels of oil, increasing its global reserves by 20 percent, Clarence Cazalot, Marathon's president, said on a conference call. The purchase is expected to close in January. The acquisition will double Marathon's West Africa output, a spokesman, Roger Holliday, said. The company has stakes in fields off the coasts of Gabon and Angola. CMS, a Michigan utility owner, is shedding assets outside the United States to expand its North American businesses.

abstract: Danish company, D/S Progress, whose oil tanker sailed into Baltimore Harbor with rust hole in its hull, pleads guilty to trying to conceal leak and deliberately polluting harbor in Mar 2000; agrees to fine of at least $250,000; captain and two supervisors, who were also charged, are fugitives (S)

lead_paragraph: A Danish company whose oil tanker sailed into Baltimore Harbor with a rust hole in its hull pleaded guilty to trying to conceal the leak and deliberately polluting the harbor. The indictment included not only the captain but also two supervisors. While the company, D/S Progress, agreed to a fine of at least $250,000, the people who were charged are fugitives, prosecutors said. When the ship, the Freja Jutlandic, arrived in Baltimore on March 22, 2000, a crew member warned a Coast Guard inspector of the hole. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Comstock Resources Inc., which explores and drills for oil and natural gas in Texas, Louisiana and the Gulf of Mexico, offered to buy a rival, DevX Energy Inc., for about $93.3 million. Comstock is offering to buy DevX common stock for $7.32 a share. In September, DevX, which is based in Dallas, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had about 12.75 million shares outstanding. The offer is 41 percent more than DevX's closing price on Friday of $5.20.

lead_paragraph: A federal grand jury in Anchorage indicted Daniel Carson Lewis, 37, on Thursday on weapons charges stemming from the shooting of the Alaska oil pipeline on Oct. 4, spilling 285,000 gallons of oil. In addition to federal indictment for unlawful possession of a firearm, Mr. Lewis will stand trial in December on several state charges, including assault and criminal mischief. He faces up to 32 years in prison, and may have to pay the state and oil companies for the cleanup and lost oil. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

abstract: Alaska Permanent Fund begins distributing to state residents $1.09 billion from state's revenue on Arctic oil extraction (S)
snippet: Alaska Permanent Fund begins distributing to state residents $1.09 billion from state's revenue on Arctic oil extraction (S)
lead_paragraph: While many retailers are seeing weak sales, merchants in Alaska are preparing for an annual shopping spree rivaling that of the holidays. Last week, the Alaska Permanent Fund began distributing dividends from the state's oil revenue savings account into the bank accounts of eligible Alaskans -- $1,850.28 for everyone who has lived in the state for at least a year, or $1.09 billion. The dividends equal 11 percent of annual wages. The fund is ''one of our biggest basic industries now,'' besides fishing, mining and tourism, said Oliver Scott Goldsmith, an economist with the University of Alaska.

abstract: Conoco Inc agrees to sell eight oil and natural gas properties in Gulf of Mexico to Stone Energy Corp for about $300 million (S)
snippet: Conoco Inc agrees to sell eight oil and natural gas properties in Gulf of Mexico to Stone Energy Corp for about $300 million (S)
lead_paragraph: Conoco Inc., the fourth-largest oil company, agreed to sell eight oil and natural gas properties in the Gulf of Mexico to the Stone Energy Corporation for about $300 million. Proceeds will be used to pay debt, a Conoco spokeswoman, Caroline Churchill, said. Conoco, based in Houston, said the sale would not affect its exploration and production in the gulf's deep waters. Stone Energy said yesterday that it agreed to buy an undisclosed number of gulf properties for as much as $300 million. Stone, an oil and gas explorer based in Lafayette, La., did not disclose the seller. Other companies with interests in the properties have bidding rights, and the final price for the transaction depends on which owners choose to exercise their rights, Conoco said. The sale to Stone Energy is expected to close Dec. 31, Conoco said.

abstract: BG Group of Britain acquires oil and natural gas fields of Enron Corp in India for $338 million (S)
snippet: BG Group of Britain acquires oil and natural gas fields of Enron Corp in India for $338 million (S)
lead_paragraph: The BG Group of Britain agreed to buy the oil and natural gas fields of Enron in India for $388 million. The operations include a 30 percent stake in the Tapti gas field and the Panna/Mukhta oil and gas fields, plus 63 percent of an untapped deposit on the country's west coast. BG said the assets held more than 170 million barrels of oil and gas. They do not include Enron's Dabhol Power project, which has been entangled in a nine-month payment dispute with the Maharashtra State Electricity Board. Enron is looking to sell its 64 percent stake in the project for $1.2 billion to cover the cost of its investment. Tata Power and BSES, both of India, have indicated an interest, people close to the talks said. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

While investors in the proposed one-million-barrel-a-day pipeline project, supported by the United States, have started a $120 million detailed engineering study, the Kazakh government has been working since this spring on putting together a sponsors' group of local and foreign oil companies operating in Kazakhstan. lead_paragraph: Members of Congress have largely resisted the temptation to exploit this moment of national crisis to promote pet causes. One exception is a small group of senators and House members, led by Senator James Inhofe, an Oklahoma Republican, who favor opening up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling. Last week Mr. Inhofe threatened to take the energy bill passed earlier this year by the House and add it as an amendment to the high-priority Defense Department authorization bill. The energy bill includes a provision opening the refuge to drilling.

abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column reports that as Sept 11 shock fades some old refrains are being heard, from left and right, about 'war for oil'; explains that oil is part of background to terrorist attacks, via Osama bin Laden's hatred of US forces in Saudi Arabia; says there is no way for now to escape awkward realitiy that Mideast oil reserves are crucial to world economy (M)
snippet: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column reports that as Sept 11 shock fades some old refrains are being heard, from left and right, about 'war for oil'; explains that oil is part of background to terrorist attacks, via Osama bin Laden's hatred of US forces in S...
lead_paragraph: As the shock of Sept. 11 has faded, we've started to hear a few old slogans. A handful of people on the left claim that we are about to start a ''war for oil.'' A considerably larger and more influential group on the right seems, oddly enough, to agree, though these people draw a different policy conclusion: that the terrorist attack means we should drill in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

lead_paragraph: Justice authorities said they had sent evidence to American investigators concerning some of the 13 bank accounts blocked on suspicion of corrupt activities by United States oil companies in Kazakhstan. Folco Galli, a Justice Department spokesman, confirmed that information had been sent last week about possible transfers to Swiss accounts of money belonging to Kazakh officials. Swiss court documents indicate the investigation centers on payments to the Kazakh president, Nursultan Nazarbayev, and other senior officials from an American identified as ''G.'' Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group lowers its target for annual growth in oil and natural gas output to 3 percent; forecast is cut from average of 5 percent growth a year through 2005; company takes action because of slowing demand for energy and delays in new fields in Africa and Middle East (S)
snippet: Royal Dutch/Shell Group lowers its target for annual growth in oil and natural gas output to 3 percent; forecast is cut from average of 5 percent growth a year through 2005; company takes action because of slowing demand for energy and delays in n...
lead_paragraph: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Europe's largest oil company, has lowered its target for annual growth in oil and natural gas output to 3 percent. The company said it took the action because of slowing demand for energy and delays with new fields in Africa and the Middle East. The forecast was cut from an average of 5 percent growth a year through 2005. Shell's new goal is the same as its larger rival, the Exxon Mobil Corporation, though lower than those of smaller peers like BP and TotalFinaElf.

abstract: Federal grand jury in Seattle indicts Olympic Pipe Line Company and Equilon Pipeline Company on negligence charges stemming from pipeline explosion that killed three people near downtown Bellingham in June 1999 (S)
snippet: Federal grand jury in Seattle indicts Olympic Pipe Line Company and Equilon Pipeline Company on negligence charges stemming from pipeline explosion that killed three people near downtown Bellingham in June 1999 (S)
lead_paragraph: A federal grand jury in Seattle has indicted two companies and three employees on negligence charges stemming from a pipeline explosion in June 1999 that killed three people near downtown Bellingham. The indictment says the companies -- the Olympic Pipe Line Company and the Equilon Pipeline Company -- were responsible for the leak of about 236,000 gallons of gasoline from a 400-mile pipeline. The leak ignited, killing two 10-year-old boys and an 18-year old man. The companies are accused of violating the Clean Water Act and the Hazardous Liquid Pipeline Safety Act. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

abstract: Chevron Corp's $46.3 billion purchase of Texaco Inc gains unanimous Federal Trade Commission approval (S)
snippet: Chevron Corp's $46.3 billion purchase of Texaco Inc gains unanimous Federal Trade Commission approval (S)
lead_paragraph: The Chevron Corporation's $46.3 billion purchase of Texaco Inc. to form the world's fourth-largest investor-owned oil company was unanimously approved by the Federal Trade Commission. Texaco agreed to sell the refining and marketing assets in the United States that in 1998 were placed in joint ventures with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Saudi Arabian oil company. Those assets will be placed in a trust because negotiations have stalled over the price Shell would pay for Texaco's share in the two ventures. Trustees will oversee the sale of Texaco's shares in Equilon Enterprises LLC and Motiva Enterprises LLC. Texaco owns 44 percent of Equilon, which was formed with Shell to serve the U.S. Midwest and West.

abstract: Venezuela's energy and mines minister, Alvaro Silva, says OPEC does not plan to make any changes in production levels at its next meeting because oil prices are likely to rise as result of group's most recent production cutback (S)
snippet: Venezuela's energy and mines minister, Alvaro Silva, says OPEC does not plan to make any changes in production levels at its next meeting because oil prices are likely to rise as result of group's most recent production cutback (S)
lead_paragraph: The Venezuelan energy and mines minister, Alvaro Silva, said yesterday the Organization of the Oil Producing Countries did not plan to make any changes in production levels at its meeting later this month because oil prices were likely to rise as a result of the group's most recent production cutback. ''We expect prices to move into the upper half of the $22-to-$28-a-barrel range,'' Mr. Silva said at a news conference. ''We don't expected changes at the next meeting.'' OPEC, which pumps about 40 percent of the world's oil, cut production by 1 million barrels a day, or 4.1 percent, effective Sept. 1.

abstract: Owners of 54 businesses in towns around Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming, send Pres Bush letter urging him to stop oil and gas drilling in three areas near park; hold tourism is more important to region than mineral extraction (S)
snippet: Owners of 54 businesses in towns around Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming, send Pres Bush letter urging him to stop oil and gas drilling in three areas near park; hold tourism is more important to region than mineral extraction (S)
lead_paragraph: The owners of 54 businesses in towns around Yellowstone National Park sent a letter to President Bush, urging him to stop oil and gas drilling in three areas near the park because it is hurting the local economy. Arguing that tourism is more important to the region than mineral extraction, the letter says in part, ''Our way of life is severely endangered by the prospect of oil and gas drilling, which will industrialize'' the area. The owners said the areas in question were the Bridger-Teton National Forest, the Upper Green River Basin and the Red Desert. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

abstract: Federal report shows environmental damage from grounding of oil freighter on Oregon coast in 1999 was much greater than thought; says oil killed 2,358 birds, including 252 marbled murreulets that are endangered species; photo (S)
snippet: Federal report shows environmental damage from grounding of oil freighter on Oregon coast in 1999 was much greater than thought; says oil killed 2,358 birds, including 252 marbled murreulets that are endangered species; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: A federal report shows that the environmental damage from the grounding of a freighter on the Oregon coast in 1999 was much greater than thought. Scientists now say oil from the wreckage of the freighter, the New Carissa, killed 2,358 birds, including 262 marbled murrelets, an endangered species. Larry Mangan, a biologist with the United States Bureau of Land Management in Coos Bay, said the government hoped to gain money for restoring the coastline from a lawsuit against the ship's owners. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

snippet: Two local residents file suit against 15 oil companies to force cleanup of leaks from gas stations that may have contaminated water in homes with private wells in Greenbush neighborhood of Hyde Park, NY (S)
lead_paragraph: Two local residents have filed suit against 15 oil companies to force the cleanup of leaks from gas stations that may have contaminated water in homes with private wells. The Greenbush neighborhood of Hyde Park was told last year by the State Department of Environmental Conservation that its water might have been contaminated by methyl tertiary butyl ether, an additive that may cause cancer. Marc J. Bern, the plaintiffs' lawyer, said more than 100 suits were planned. Robert Worth (NYT)

abstract: EUROPE CHINA: PROFIT FALLS AT OIL COMPANY The Chinese offshore oil company CNOOC reported a 4.2 percent drop in net profit in the first half of the year as it began paying higher taxes, and said it planned an acquisition this year to reinforce its offshore monopoly. CNOOC said net profit fell to 4.62 billion yuan ($558 million) from 4.82 billion yuan, in line with analysts' forecasts, as it started to pay a tax of 30 percent on profit. Previously, it had paid only 15 percent but it had said taxes would be doubling. The company, listed in Hong Kong and New York in February, said its earnings before taxes rose 11.3 percent year on year.   (Reuters) THAILAND: PHONE CONCERN SURGES Stock in Advanced Info Service, which serves more than half of Thailand's mobile phone users, surged to a five-year high on optimism it would post a record profit. Advanced Info Service, controlled by the family of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, left, rose 20 baht, or 4.3 percent, to 490 baht ($11), the highest level since 1996. Advanced Info said last week that it added a record number of subscribers for a fourth consecutive month in July. It has 3.27 million total subscribers.   (Bloomberg News) SOUTH AFRICA SOUTH AFRICA: GOLD MINING SHIFT AngloGold, the biggest gold miner in the world, said it hoped to more than double annual production from South America to one million ounces within five years, reducing dependence on high-cost South African mines. The company could increase South American production from last year's 439,000 ounces by buying out minority partners, expanding mines it owns and digging new pits to produce metal that would be worth about $273 million a year at current prices.   (Bloomberg News) EUROPE THE NETHERLANDS: NO RUSH TO DEAL The Dutch telecommunications group Royal KPN appears to be in no rush to make a deal with its southern neighbor, the Belgian government-controlled Belgacom. abstract: Lukoil, largest Russian oil producer, plans to put red and blue dyes into gasoline it produces to distinguish it from low-quality bootleg gasoline being sold under its trademark (S)
snippet: Lukoil, largest Russian oil producer, plans to put red and blue dyes into gasoline it produces to distinguish it from low-quality bootleg gasoline being sold under its trademark (S)
lead_paragraph: The largest oil producer in Russia, Lukoil, said yesterday that it planned to put red and blue dyes into the gasoline it produces to fight bootleggers who sell low-quality fuel under the company's trademark, Bloomberg News reported. As Lukoil moves to international quality standards for its gasoline, it is trying to stamp out illegal sales under its brand name. The company has already begun experimenting with dyed fuel in the Volgograd and Perm regions. Sales from those regions rose one-fifth after Lukoil began dyeing the fuel it markets there. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

abstract: AUSTRALIA NEW ZEALAND: WINERY PURSUIT DROPPED Australia's second-largest brewer, Lion Nathan, has abandoned a yearlong struggle to buy the Montana Group, one of New Zealand's largest wine companies. Lion Nathan will sell its 43 percent stake in Montana to Allied Domecq of Britain, which has been competing for control of the winery. Topping Allied's bid of 4.80 New Zealand dollars a share ($2.12) would have been too expensive, Gordon Cairns, Lion Nathan's chief, said yesterday. After the transaction, Allied will hold 70 percent of Montana, and Lion Nathan will make 127 million New Zealand dollars ($56.2 million) on the sale of its stake. Lion Nathan has identified other opportunities in the wine business, Mr. Cairns said.   Becky Gaylord (NYT) EUROPE FINLAND: SETBACK FOR SAMPO Sampo, Finland's largest insurer, suffered a setback in its $2.3 billion bid for its Norwegian rival Storebrand, when Norwegian regulators refused to lift a rule that requires financial companies to acquire more than 90 percent of a target's outstanding stock. Only 86.3 percent of Storebrand investors have turned over their shares to Sampo, not enough to secure a deal under the requirements. The Norwegian government was widely expected to enforce the rule, in part because it did not want the country's largest insurer to fall into foreign ownership. Den Norske Bank, Norway's largest bank, has hindered the deal by refusing to sell its almost 10 percent stake in Storebrand to Sampo.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT) FRANCE: TEST FLIGHT FOR CONCORDE Air France took a Concorde jet for a test flight for the first time since one crashed into a hotel shortly after takeoff on July 25, 2000, killing 113 people. A burst tire was blamed. To prevent similar accidents, the plane now has tougher tires and Kevlar-lined fuel tanks. The test plane broke the sound barrier on a two-and-a-half-hour flight over the Atlantic, but did not reach its Mach 2 cruising speed. British Airways has alr

abstract: EUROPE RUSSIA: GAZPROM JOINS IN CHINA BID The natural gas company in Russia, Gazprom, has received approval from the largest oil company in China, PetroChina, to join the Royal Dutch/Shell Group in a consortium to bid for a $6 billion pipeline. Gazprom and Shell will compete with two other consortiums led by units of BP and the Exxon Mobil Corporation. PetroChina is expected to decide in September which group will build the 2,600- mile pipeline that will link the western Xinjiang province with eastern Shanghai.   Sabrina Tavernise (NYT) GERMANY: DEUTSCHE POST INCOME Deutsche Post said yesterday that its net income fell 5 percent in the first half, but its profit and sales rose. The company said its profit was 1.05 billion euros ($960 million) in the first half, down from 1.1 billion euros a year ago. The chairman, Klaus Zumwinkel, said the drop was largely because of scheduled tax charges. Operating profit was up 5.5 percent at 1.41 billion euros ($1.29 billion).   (AP) GERMANY: BID FOR BANK JC Flowers & Company, a brokerage firm started by a former partner of the Goldman Sachs Group, Christopher Flowers, plans to bid for Bankgesellschaft Berlin, which had a loss of $1.4 billion last year. David Schamis, a principal at JC Flowers, said the company wanted to buy at least 75 percent of the bank. Losses at Bank Berlin, 56.6 percent owned by the city, will almost triple the city government's budget deficit this year.   (Bloomberg News) THE AMERICAS CANADA: INFLATION SLOWS Canada's inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, slowed to 2.6 percent for the year to July, Statistics Canada reported. The drop, from 3.3 percent in June and 3.9 percent in May, was largely because of lower energy prices, including a 9.6 percent drop in gasoline and an 8.4 percent decline in natural gas. Cheaper energy bills were partly offset by a 4.6 percent rise in food prices. Excluding food, energy and other volatile items, the c

abstract: Editorial says Chevron and Texaco have proposed promising merger plan that addresses fact that combined company would face more competition as explorer, extractor, creditor and buyer abroad than as seller at home; notes that Texaco has offered to sell all its domestic refining and gasoline-selling assets; says plan may not completely satisfy Federal Trade Commission, but Chevron and Texaco have taken first step in right direction
snippet: Editorial says Chevron and Texaco have proposed promising merger plan that addresses fact that combined company would face more competition as explorer, extractor, creditor and buyer abroad than as seller at home; notes that Texaco has offered to ...
lead_paragraph: When American companies cite foreign competition to justify blockbuster mergers, regulators should be careful to check whether that competition extends down to consumers. Oil companies, like car makers and airlines, face fierce global competition when it comes to production and financing. But they cater to domestic markets that are often less sharply contested. Last Friday Chevron and Texaco proposed a promising merger plan that begins to address this duality.

abstract: Fishing vessel that sank in Alaska's Prince William Sound is leaking 35,000 gallons of fuel (S)
snippet: Fishing vessel that sank in Alaska's Prince William Sound is leaking 35,000 gallons of fuel (S)
lead_paragraph: A fishing vessel that sank in Prince William Sound on Saturday is leaking 35,000 gallons of diesel fuel. Cleanup crews reached the scene the same day, but the effort was tapering off after about 11,000 gallons were collected. A 10-square-mile sheen remained but was expected to evaporate. The fuel reached land in at least three places. One oiled bird was captured for treatment. The spill was the largest in the sound since the Exxon Valdez leaked 11 million gallons of crude oil in 1989. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column on Pres Bush's expressions of sympathy for OPEC's cause; suggests that his heart belongs to people, of whatever nationality, who sell oil (S)

lead_paragraph: George W. Bush said something interesting about economics the other day. No, really. It wasn't his usual line about how tax cuts are the answer to whatever ails you; he said something unscripted, something that reflected what he really thinks and feels. You might say that his remarks gave us a sense of his soul. And it turns out that his soul -- or maybe it's just his heart -- belongs to people, of whatever nationality, who sell oil.

abstract: Tesoro Petroleum, which refines oil in Washington State, Alaska and Hawaii, says that third-quarter earnings will fall short of analysts' projections; says that second-quarter profit more than doubled, with net income rising to $29.5 million, from $14.6 million (S)
snippet: Tesoro Petroleum, which refines oil in Washington State, Alaska and Hawaii, says that third-quarter earnings will fall short of analysts' projections; says that second-quarter profit more than doubled, with net income rising to $29.5 million, from...
lead_paragraph: Tesoro Petroleum, which has oil refineries in Alaska, Hawaii and Washington State, said yesterday that it would fall short of analysts' estimates for third-quarter earnings because profit margins had fallen. Tesoro, based in San Antonio, expects to earn 10 to 25 cents a share; analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected 34 cents. Tesoro said second-quarter profit more than doubled, helped by high refining margins in April and May. After a payment of preferred dividends, net income rose to $29.5 million, or 70 cents a share, from $14.6 million, or 35 cents.

abstract: House roll-call votes passing energy bill, defeating significant increases in motor vehicle fuel economy standards and rejecting attempt to ban drilling in Arctic National Wildlife Refuge (M)
snippet: House roll-call votes passing energy bill, defeating significant increases in motor vehicle fuel economy standards and rejecting attempt to ban drilling in Arctic National Wildlife Refuge (M)
lead_paragraph: Following are the roll-call votes in the House on Wednesday and early yesterday passing an energy bill, defeating significant increases in motor vehicle fuel economy standards and rejecting an attempt to ban drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. The vote on the full bill was 240 to 189, with 36 Democrats, 203 Republicans and 1 independent voting for the bill and 172 Democrats, 16 Republicans and 1 independent voting against it. The vote on fuel standards was 269 to 160, with 123 Democrats, 36 Republicans and 1 independent supporting high standards and 86 Democrats, 182 Republicans and 1 independent opposing them. The vote on drilling in the refuge was 223 to 206, as 171 Democrats, 34 Republicans and 1 independent supported the ban, while 36 Democrats, 186 Republicans and 1 independent opposed it. There is one vacancy in the House.

abstract: Engelhard Corp, maker of catalysts that reduce emissions from vehicles and industrial processes, will cut 200 jobs, mostly in Georgia, as part of plan to increase its petroleum-refining catalyst business (S)
snippet: Engelhard Corp, maker of catalysts that reduce emissions from vehicles and industrial processes, will cut 200 jobs, mostly in Georgia, as part of plan to increase its petroleum-refining catalyst business (S)
lead_paragraph: The Engelhard Corporation, a maker of catalysts that reduce emissions from vehicles and industrial processes, said it would cut 200 jobs as part of a plan to increase its petroleum-refining catalyst business. Most of the jobs will be eliminated in Georgia, Engelhard said. The company, which is based in Iselin, N.J., said it took a related second-quarter charge of $7.1 million. Engelhard will consolidate its kaolin operations in Georgia that make products for the paper industry and its petroleum-refining catalyst plant in Savannah, Ga.

abstract: Editorial scores energy bill pending in House; backs bid to kill provision that would open Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration; backs amendment to require sports utility vehicles to meet same fuel economy standards as cars
snippet: Editorial scores energy bill pending in House; backs bid to kill provision that would open Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration; backs amendment to require sports utility vehicles to meet same fuel economy standards as cars
lead_paragraph: In a rational world, the members of the House of Representatives would disappear on their August vacation this Friday without touching the energy bill that lies before them, then start all over again in September. The bill is a mishmash of four smaller measures written by four separate committees. It runs to 511 pages, which few members have actually digested. It contains some useful suggestions to improve electricity transmission and streamline the distribution of natural gas. It also has modest subsidies for alternative fuels like wind and solar power and modest tax credits for energy-efficient cars and homes. On the whole, however, it is a dismal compendium of tired ideas favoring the coal, oil and gas industries.

snippet: Sens Dianne Feinstein and Olympia Snowe Op-Ed article urges Congress to set same fuel efficiency standards for sports utility vehicles and light trucks as for cars; holds move could both limit dependence on foreign oil and slow global warming; pro...
lead_paragraph: Requiring sport utility vehicles and other light trucks to go farther on a gallon of gas is the most effective step America could take both to limit dependence on foreign oil and to slow global warming, yet for years Congress has not taken it. The report issued yesterday by the National Academy of Sciences, asserting that this improvement is not only environmentally critical but technically feasible, gives solid support to those of us in Congress who have long wanted to set the same fuel efficiency standards for S.U.V.'s and light trucks that we now set for cars.

abstract: Michigan Lieutenant Governor Dick Posthumus says he opposes drilling for oil and natural gas under Great Lakes, breaking ranks with Gov John Engler over issue; photo (S)
snippet: Michigan Lieutenant Governor Dick Posthumus says he opposes drilling for oil and natural gas under Great Lakes, breaking ranks with Gov John Engler over issue; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The state's lieutenant governor, Dick Posthumus, left, said this week that he opposed drilling for oil and gas under the Great Lakes, breaking ranks with Gov. John Engler over the issue. Mr. Engler, a Republican like Mr. Posthumus, has said he wants to lift a 1997 moratorium and allow expanded drilling under the lakes, saying the environmental risks are negligible and the potential for oil and gas significant. Opponents say it could harm shoreline habitats and would yield only small amounts of energy. There are seven wells drilled on the shore and reaching deep under the waters of Lakes Michigan and Huron. Mr. Posthumus is expected to seek the Republican nomination for governor in 2002, when Mr. Engler must leave office because of term limits. Pam Belluck (NYT)

snippet: Zimbabwe, cash-strapped and facing fuel shortage, brokers $360 million deal with Libya to exhange local products for oil (S)
lead_paragraph: The government, which has been desperately short of hard currency to pay for fuel imports, has brokered a $360 million deal with oil-rich Libya, according to news reports from the capital, Harare. In exchange for the fuel, Zimbabwe will export local products to Libya. The fuel shortage has heightened discontent in the struggling nation, and easing the problem is a crucial hurdle for the government, which faces national elections early next year. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

abstract: The grumbling last week over "faith-based initiative," a signature issues in President Bush's domestic agenda, was a reminder of the gap between Mr. Bush and the moderate wing of his Congressional party
snippet: The grumbling last week over "faith-based initiative," a signature issues in President Bush's domestic agenda, was a reminder of the gap between Mr. Bush and the moderate wing of his Congressional party
lead_paragraph: Last week's brief rebellion by Republican moderates in the House over President Bush's "faith- based initiative" ended tamely with vague promises from the White House to review complaints that the bill would override state and local anti-discrimination laws. Still, the grumbling over one of the signature issues in Mr. Bush's domestic agenda was a reminder of the gap between Mr. Bush and the moderate wing of his Congressional party. Republican moderates in Congress, in turn, reflect the feelings of their constituents — voters who supported Mr. Bush but do not like the policy trends of his administration on certain key issues.

abstract: Kaztransoil, Kazakhstan's national oil transportation company, issues $150 million in Eurobonds in country's first corporate bond issue (S)
snippet: Kaztransoil, Kazakhstan's national oil transportation company, issues $150 million in Eurobonds in country's first corporate bond issue (S)
lead_paragraph: Kazakhstan's national oil transportation company, Kaztransoil, has issued $150 million of Eurobonds in the country's first corporate bond issue. The bonds, which have a face value of 8.5 percent and yield 8.67 percent, mature in 2006. The lead manager for the issue, which was oversubscribed, was J. P. Morgan. It was sold to more than 30 investors, split evenly in the United States and Europe. J. P. Morgan's managing director, Richard Luddington, said the issue was an important step in the development of a capital market in Kazakhstan, the major issuer of government bonds in the former Soviet Union. Kaztransoil will use the proceeds for a pipeline in western Kazakhstan. Birgit Brauer (NYT)

abstract: Survey by Westchester County (NY) Department of Consumer Protection finds that average price for regular gasoline has dropped three cents from May, to $1.861 a gallon (S)
snippet: Survey by Westchester County (NY) Department of Consumer Protection finds that average price for regular gasoline has dropped three cents from May, to $1.861 a gallon (S)
lead_paragraph: Motorists planning summer trips this month will find gasoline prices have dropped since May. In its survey of gasoline prices on June 28, the Westchester County Department of Consumer Protection found that the average price for regular gasoline was $1.861, down three cents from May. Many stations, the survey also found, are selling regular gasoline below $1.80. The lowest price for regular gasoline on June 28 was $1.699 in Cortlandt; the highest price was found in Bedford at $2.14.

Iraq, which stopped exporting oil in early June to protest possible changes in the program -- but failed to push oil prices way up -- may resume exports in a matter of days. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

The point of the exercise was to understand, firsthand, the difficulty of international environmental negotiations. Taking on the roles of diplomats and N.G.O.'s, we learned how easy it is to talk about environmental issues and how hard it is to commit to action.

lead_paragraph: A small oil company is at the heart of a battle between Russia's fourth-largest oil producer, Tyumen Oil, and Norex Petroleum, a Cyprus-registered oil service company that is owned by Canadians. Tyumen took over management of the oil company, Yugraneft, which is owned jointly by Norex and a Tyumen subsidiary, after a regional court prevented Norex from voting most of its shares at a key shareholder meeting. Norex, owned in part by Alex Rotzang, a Russian-born Canadian national, said the takeover was illegal and pledged to fight it in court.

abstract: Exxon Mobil Corp and Malaysia's state oil company, Petronas Carigali, will spend $1.7 billion to develop three oil and gas projects to meet rising demand in Asia (S)
snippet: Exxon Mobil Corp and Malaysia's state oil company, Petronas Carigali, will spend $1.7 billion to develop three oil and gas projects to meet rising demand in Asia (S)
lead_paragraph: The Exxon Mobil Corporation and Malaysia's state oil company will spend $1.7 billion to develop three oil and gas projects to meet rising demand in Asia, an official said. Exxon is the largest oil producer in the country. It supplies 70 percent of natural gas needs of the Malaysian peninsula. The three projects off Malaysia's east coast will be able to produce 133,000 barrels a day of oil, and 345 million cubic feet a day of gas, offsetting a decline in output from existing projects. The projects are ventures with Petronas Carigali, a unit of Petroliam Nasional, the state oil and gas company of Malaysia.

lead_paragraph: A proposal by the federal government to study oil drilling off the New Jersey coast and elsewhere on the Eastern Seaboard was raise and then scrapped last week after protests. The Interior Department had proposed an 18-month study of the impact and feasibility of drilling for oil and natural gas off the Atlantic coastline. The proposed study generated protests from members of Congress, the State Legislature and environmental groups. Karen DeMasters

abstract: Cabot Oil and Gas Corp acquires Cody Co for $230 million in cash and stock to increase gas and oil reserves in Texas and Louisiana (S)
snippet: Cabot Oil and Gas Corp acquires Cody Co for $230 million in cash and stock to increase gas and oil reserves in Texas and Louisiana (S)
lead_paragraph: The Cabot Oil and Gas Corporation, a natural gas explorer and producer, agreed to buy the Cody Company for $230 million in cash and stock to increase gas and oil reserves in Texas and Louisiana. Cabot will pay $168 million in cash and $62 million in stock or cash at its option. The purchase will increase Cabot's oil and gas holdings by 16 percent, adding 166 billion cubic feet of gas and oil reserves. Cabot is based in Houston. Cody, which is based in Denver, has a daily production of about 50 million cubic feet, which comes mainly from natural gas.

abstract: Federal Judge Claudia Wilken blocks any
snippet: Federal Judge Claudia Wilken blocks any
lead_paragraph: Judge Claudia Wilken of Federal District Court in Oakland blocked any effort to explore oil and natural gas deposits off the central coast until the federal government conducts environmental reviews and the state approves a plan. No drilling has been conducted since 1989, and no immediate plans for new rigs are pending, but the state and the Natural Resources Defense Council sued to block even preliminary exploration after the Clinton administration extended dozens of leases in 1999, arguing that the state had the right to review any plan. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

abstract: Oregon lawmakers complete bill to give residents who use gardening tools powered by gasoline refund of state gasoline tax, which is 24 cents per gallon (S)
snippet: Oregon lawmakers complete bill to give residents who use gardening tools powered by gasoline refund of state gasoline tax, which is 24 cents per gallon (S)
lead_paragraph: People who cut their lawns may be about to cut their taxes, too -- though not by much. Lawmakers are completing a bill to give Oregonians who use ''power lawn mowers, leaf blowers, chain saws and similar implements'' a refund of the state gasoline tax, which is 24 cents a gallon. Proponents say the Oregon Constitution requires that gasoline taxes from road users must be spent on roads, and that other users are eligible for rebates. An average homeowner would be eligible for about 48 cents a month in rebates. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

abstract: Connecticut Gov John G Rowland will announce whether he will sign into law or veto bill to tighten emissions standards on Connecticut's six most polluting coal- and oil-burning power plants (S)
snippet: Connecticut Gov John G Rowland will announce whether he will sign into law or veto bill to tighten emissions standards on Connecticut's six most polluting coal- and oil-burning power plants (S)
lead_paragraph: Gov. John G. Rowland is to announce today whether he will sign into law or veto a bill to tighten emissions standards on Connecticut's six most polluting coal- and oil-burning power plants. Mr. Rowland must act by midnight or the bill automatically becomes law. He had postponed a decision as letters criticizing the legislation came in from both the power plants' owner, NRG Energy Inc., and a regional director of the United States Environmental Protection Agency. Mr. Rowland said he was concerned that passage of the bill would leave the state short on power this summer. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

abstract: Kidnapping of 10 oil-field workers in Ecuador on Oct 12, 2000, offers case study of what not to do when kidnappers seize workers for sole purpose of extracting money from their employers; kidnappers demanded $80 million from Ehlmerich & Payne Inc, Erickson Air-Crane and Schlumberger, but companies gambled with low bid of $500,000 only to start frantically raising it after kidnappers killed a hostage, Ronald Sander; seven workers -- two of the original 10 having escaped on their own -- were freed for $13 million 141 days after being seized; families feel betrayed by companies they trusted; some of survivors are still struggling with deep emotional tremors; Colombian government has arrested 52 people suspected of playing role in this kidnapping as well as others reaching back several years; kidnapping for money, not for ideological or political goal, has become one of biggest overseas worries for American corporations; photos; map (L)

abstract: Interior Sec Gale A Norton names oil development lobbyist, Cam Toohey, as her special assistant for Alaska; apointment draws denunciation from environmental groups and Rep Edward J Markey; Norton also announces appointment of Drue Pearce, former State Senate president and drilling proponent, as senior adviser on Alaska issues (S)
snippet: Interior Sec Gale A Norton names oil development lobbyist, Cam Toohey, as her special assistant for Alaska; apointment draws denunciation from environmental groups and Rep Edward J Markey; Norton also announces appointment of Drue Pearce, former S...
lead_paragraph: The head of a group that lobbies for oil development in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge has been named by Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton as her special assistant for Alaska. The appointment of the lobbyist, Cam Toohey, the director for the past five years of Arctic Power, based in Anchorage, drew denunciations from environmental groups and Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, who called the appointment ''an ethical oil spill.'' Ms. Norton also announced the appointment of Drue Pearce, a former State Senate president and a drilling proponent, as a senior adviser on Alaska issues. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Choice Hotels cast its eye upon the pump and decided its summer promotion would be gasoline. So until Aug. 31, families reserving in advance, paying with a MasterCard and staying two nights at a Comfort, Quality, Clarion, Sleep Inn or MainStay Suites brand hotel, receive a plastic card good for $5 worth of gas. The cards are good for six brands: BP Amoco, Arco, Citgo, Exxon, Shell or Tesoro. But hurry: the way gas prices are rising, by the end of summer, the cards may be good for about two gallons each. Choice reservations: (800) 424-6423 or www.choicehotels.com. BETSY WADE

abstract: China's Hong Kong-listed oil refiner, Sinopec, will buy Sinopec National Star, China's fourth-largest oil company, from its parent for $779 million (US) (S)
snippet: China's Hong Kong-listed oil refiner, Sinopec, will buy Sinopec National Star, China's fourth-largest oil company, from its parent for $779 million (US) (S)
lead_paragraph: China's Hong Kong-listed oil refiner, Sinopec, said it would buy Sinopec National Star, China's No. 4 oil company, from its parent for 6.45 billion yuan ($779 million). It said the purchase was intended to add to the listed company's oil and gas production and give it more stable earnings. Sinopec will also assume National Star's net debt, which was about 2.68 billion yuan at end of last year. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

abstract: Yukos Oil Co, Russia's second-largest producer, buys more than a quarter of Mazeikiu Nafta, Lithuanian oil refinery managed by Williams International, for $75 million (S)
snippet: Yukos Oil Co, Russia's second-largest producer, buys more than a quarter of Mazeikiu Nafta, Lithuanian oil refinery managed by Williams International, for $75 million (S)
lead_paragraph: Russia's second-largest oil producer, the Yukos Oil Company, bought more than a quarter of a Lithuanian oil refinery, managed by Williams International of the United States, according to Bloomberg News. Yukos agreed to pay $75 million for a 26.85 percent stake in the refinery, which is called Mazeikiu Nafta and is the only refinery in the Baltic States. Yukos, which beat an offer by a rival Russian oil company, said it would guarantee crude oil supplies for 10 years to the refinery, the agency reported. Williams owns a 33 percent stake in the refinery, which it bought two years ago for $150 million. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

abstract: Study by Rutgers University Profs Jocelyn Crowley and John A Spry finds that gasoline and food prices on New Jersey toll roads are higher than nearest off-highway gas stations and eateries (S)
snippet: Study by Rutgers University Profs Jocelyn Crowley and John A Spry finds that gasoline and food prices on New Jersey toll roads are higher than nearest off-highway gas stations and eateries (S)
lead_paragraph: A study by two Rutgers professors confirms what is probably obvious to New Jersey toll-road drivers: motorists pay more for gas and food there than they would if they got off at the nearest exit. Jocelyn Crowley and John A. Spry did first-hand research May 17 through May 21 and found gas prices to be at least five cents per gallon higher on the New Jersey Turnpike, Atlantic City Expressway and Garden State Parkway than at the nearest off-highway gas stations. Similarly, food prices tended to be much higher on the toll roads. Ms. Crowley recommended allowing off-road establishments to advertise on the toll highways and putting more, competing vendors in rest areas. Robert Strauss

abstract: New York Taxi Workers Alliance, concerned about rising cost of gasoline, wants to add 50-cent fuel surcharge to fares; photo (S)
snippet: New York Taxi Workers Alliance, concerned about rising cost of gasoline, wants to add 50-cent fuel surcharge to fares; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: A cabdrivers organization, worried about the rising cost of gasoline, wants to add a 50-cent fuel surcharge to fares. The group, the New York Taxi Workers Alliance, said that instead of netting an average $75 per 12-hour day, drivers were going home with $60. ''If airlines and landlords are able to raise prices because of increased costs, why not working-class taxi drivers?'' said Bhairavi Desai, their spokeswoman. But the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission said it would need detailed data before it would consider the request. Hope Reeves (NYT)

abstract: Bush administration authorizes money for study on $2.8 billion oil pipeline from Azerbaijani capital of Baku to Turkish Mediterranean port of Ceyhan; Stephen Mann, new senior adviser for Caspian Basin energy diplomacy, signs $346,000 grant, from US Trade and Development Agency to Kazakhstan's national oil transportation company (S)
snippet: Bush administration authorizes money for study on $2.8 billion oil pipeline from Azerbaijani capital of Baku to Turkish Mediterranean port of Ceyhan; Stephen Mann, new senior adviser for Caspian Basin energy diplomacy, signs $346,000 grant, from U...
lead_paragraph: The Bush administration has authorized money for a study on a $2.8 billion oil pipeline from the Azerbaijani capital of Baku to the Turkish Mediterranean port of Ceyhan. The new senior adviser for Caspian Basin energy diplomacy, Stephen Mann, signed the $346,000 grant, from the United States Trade and Development Agency to Kazakhstan's national oil transportation company. The grant will pay for a study to evaluate potential routes for Kazakh oil to link up with the pipeline. The study will also examine whether Kazakhstan's only Caspian port, Aktau, can handle heavy tanker traffic.

abstract: Pride International Inc acquires Marine Drilling Companies for $1.9 billion in stock (S)
snippet: Pride International Inc acquires Marine Drilling Companies for $1.9 billion in stock (S)
lead_paragraph: Pride International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival oil and gas driller, the Marine Drilling Companies, for $1.9 billion in stock. Investors in the companies will get one share of a new company for each share held. The offer valued Marine at $32.65 a share, 18 percent more than Wednesday's closing price. Pride's stock fell $5.15, or 16 percent, to $27.50. Marine fell $1.17, to $26.55. After the Marine acquisition, Pride will have 246 land rigs and 77 rigs in the gulf and other waters, and employ more than 10,000 people worldwide. Shareholders of Pride will own 56 percent of the new company, which will retain the Pride name and keep its headquarters in Houston. Marine is based in Sugar Land, Tex.

snippet: Judge Jed S Rakoff of federal court in Manhattan dismisses lawsuit brought by Ecuadorean Indians nearly eight years ago accusing Texaco of polluting their land in Amazon rain forest; rules suit should have been brought in Ecuador, not US (S)
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan has dismissed a nearly eight-year-old lawsuit brought by Ecuadorean Indians against Texaco. In a ruling yesterday, Judge Jed S. Rakoff dismissed the suit, which accused Texaco of polluting the Indians' land in the Amazon rain forest, on the ground that it should have been brought in Ecuador and not in the United States. Last September, Judge Rakoff denied a motion by the Indians' lawyers to recuse himself from the case after he confirmed he had attended an expenses-paid seminar in 1998 at which a former Texaco chairman spoke.

abstract: New York City Department of Consumer Affairs padlocks Bronx gas station for selling gas with lower octane rating than advertised (S)
snippet: New York City Department of Consumer Affairs padlocks Bronx gas station for selling gas with lower octane rating than advertised (S)
lead_paragraph: The City Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday that it had padlocked a gas station for selling gas with a lower octane rating than advertised. The station, 1255 Service Gulf, at 1255 East Gunhill Road in the Bronx, was shut down after inspectors found that gas sold as 93 octane, which commands a higher price, had only a 91.4 octane content. The allowable error margin is 0.6. The padlocked station faces penalties of up to $60,000 and must bring its octane levels up to code to reopen. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

abstract: Land Management Bureau, rejecting appeal by 10 American Indian tribes and environmentalists, rules Anschutz Exploration Corp may drill exploratory oil well in southern Montana near ancient rock art site Indians consider sacred (S)
snippet: Land Management Bureau, rejecting appeal by 10 American Indian tribes and environmentalists, rules Anschutz Exploration Corp may drill exploratory oil well in southern Montana near ancient rock art site Indians consider sacred (S)
lead_paragraph: Despite protests by environmentalists and American Indians, the Bureau of Land Management ruled this week to allow exploratory drilling of one oil well in southern Montana. A decision in February to allow the Anschutz Exploration Corporation to drill was appealed by 10 tribes and environmental groups. Officials at the land bureau note that the drilling site is a quarter-mile from ancient rock art or other historic places. Tribal leaders from Oklahoma and Montana have compared the site to the Sistine Chapel and continue to hold religious ceremonies in the area they consider sacred. Mindy Sink (NYT)

abstract: Vintage Petroleum to acquire Genesis Exploration for $572 million (S)
snippet: Vintage Petroleum to acquire Genesis Exploration for $572 million (S)
lead_paragraph: Vintage Petroleum said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Genesis Exploration, a Canadian producer of oil and natural gas, for $572 million. The move enables Vintage, based in Tulsa, Okla., to bolster its presence in western Canada. Vintage will pay $11.62 for each share of Genesis, based in Calgary, Alberta. The offer is a 22 percent premium to Genesis's closing price on Tuesday of 15 Canadian dollars ($9.56) on the Toronto stock exchange. Last year, Vintage, which owns oil and gas fields, acquired Cometra Energy, which has fields in Alberta and British Columbia, for $46.3 million.

abstract: Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, is fined total of $8.9 million after recent accidents on two offshore rigs spilled nearly 400,000 gallons of oil into sea 120 miles off coast of Rio de Janeiro; is also cited for inappropriately using detergents while cleaning up smaller of two spilled, caused by uncontrolled gush of oil earlier this month (S)
snippet: Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, is fined total of $8.9 million after recent accidents on two offshore rigs spilled nearly 400,000 gallons of oil into sea 120 miles off coast of Rio de Janeiro; is also cited for...
lead_paragraph: Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petróleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, was fined a total of $8.9 million by federal environmental regulators after recent accidents on two offshore rigs spilled nearly 400,000 gallons of oil into the sea 120 miles off the coast of Rio de Janeiro. Petrobras was also cited for inappropriately using detergents while cleaning up the smaller of the two spills, caused by an uncontrolled gush of oil earlier this month. A final report on the cause of the explosion that killed 11 workers and sank the company's largest oil platform in March is still pending. Jennifer L. Rich

abstract: Oil and gas leak forces evacuation of an offshore oil rig operated by the Brazilian oil company, Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, in the latest in a string of incidents that has damaged reputation of state-owned giant (S)
snippet: Oil and gas leak forces evacuation of an offshore oil rig operated by the Brazilian oil company, Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, in the latest in a string of incidents that has damaged reputation of state-owned giant (S)
lead_paragraph: An oil and gas leak forced the evacuation of an offshore oil rig operated by the Brazilian oil company, Petróleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, in the latest in a string of incidents that has damaged the reputation of the state-owned giant. At least 3,500 gallons of oil leaked from a pipe that was being tested on the P-7 rig, which is in the Campos Basin, 75 miles off the coast of Rio de Janeiro State. Last month, a fire and explosions killed 11 workers and sank a $500 million oil platform at a nearby site. Petrobras said that the P-7 spill was being contained and that there were no injuries. Jennifer L. Rich

lead_paragraph: With gasoline prices rising, the State Senate passed a bill yesterday to eliminate the 4 percent tax on gasoline, part of a package of tax cuts the chamber approved. ''We can provide immediate relief,'' Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, said of the gas tax cut, which would save drivers $400 million a year. But Assembly Democrats said they would consider the tax cut only in the context of the state budget, and, six weeks after the fiscal year began, there have been no budget negotiations. Richard Pérez-Peña (NYT)

abstract: Editorial says Pres Bush's actions and inactions during his first four months in White House contain troubling signs about his vision of office, his ideas about exercise of executive power and his definition of scope of presidential leadership and responsiblity; cites his California trip, where he pledged funds for repair to national parks and encouraged cutting energy use in federal buildings, but flatly rejected Gov Gray Davis's pleas for short-term price relief on energy costs and did nothing to allay fears about his plans to build hundreds of new power plants and open sensitive public lands for oil and gas exploration
snippet: Editorial says Pres Bush's actions and inactions during his first four months in White House contain troubling signs about his vision of office, his ideas about exercise of executive power and his definition of scope of presidential leadership and...
lead_paragraph: President Bush has now occupied the White House for a little over four months. There is much to be said for the discipline and steadiness he has brought to the job. But at this point it is also fair to raise questions about Mr. Bush's vision of the office, his ideas about the exercise of executive power and his definition of the scope of presidential leadership and responsibility. The actions and inactions of these first months contain some troubling signs. He sometimes projects an air of detachment bordering on indifference even on issues of major concern.

snippet: Crude oil prices rise after unexplained explosion and fire at Conoco refinery in Northeastern England raises concerns about gasoline prices for US, where inventories are 5 percent lower than last year and peak summer travel season is approaching (...
lead_paragraph: Crude oil prices rose after an unexplained explosion and fire at a Conoco refinery in Northeastern England raised worries about gasoline supplies for the United States, where inventories are 5 percent lower than last year and the peak summer travel season is approaching. The refinery, which produces 200,000 barrels a day, is one of the few European suppliers to the United States. The price of Brent crude for June settlement rose in London almost 3 percent, to $28.10 a barrel. Alan Cowell

abstract: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column says Pres Bush's decision to pull United States out of Kyoto protocol on climate change may ultimately turn out to be his greatest gift to environmentalism; says serious environmental activists were left with nowhere else to turn but the market, by mobilizing consumers to fight multinational polluters on their own ground; cites current boycott against Exxon Mobil gas stations in England, because oil companies refuse to admit connection between carbon dioxide emissions and climate change; says if this spreads to United States, Exxon, big contributor to Bush campaign, may beg Bush to revive Kyoto protocol (M)
snippet: Thomas L Friedman Op-Ed column says Pres Bush's decision to pull United States out of Kyoto protocol on climate change may ultimately turn out to be his greatest gift to environmentalism; says serious environmental activists were left with nowhere...
lead_paragraph: And now for a wild prediction. Within 12 months President Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney and all their backers in the oil industry will be begging -- begging -- to revive the Kyoto protocol on climate change, the accord Mr. Bush yanked America out of after taking office.

William Hague, the party leader, said he would make necessary savings from trimming bureaucracy and uncovering fraud. Labor is 20 points ahead in the polls. Warren Hoge (NYT)

abstract: Editorial says one of more troubling proposals in Pres Bush's new energy plan is directive ordering federal officials to review Clean Air Act provisions to see whether rules governing pollution from power plants and refineries should be applied more leniently or even suspended in order to increase energy supplies; calls on Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Christie Whitman to nonetheless continue campaign to crack down on these polluters
snippet: Editorial says one of more troubling proposals in Pres Bush's new energy plan is directive ordering federal officials to review Clean Air Act provisions to see whether rules governing pollution from power plants and refineries should be applied mo...
lead_paragraph: One of the more troubling proposals in President Bush's new energy plan is a directive ordering federal officials to review an important law governing air pollution from power plants and refineries. The idea, pushed hard by such energy giants as Southern and Exxon, is to see whether this law should be applied more leniently or even suspended in order to increase supplies of electricity and natural gas. But there is no good reason to ease these rules. Keeping them in place will test the resolve of Christie Whitman, the Environmental Protection Agency boss, who has already had more than her share of run-ins with the White House.

lead_paragraph: The consortium of international oil companies exploring the Kashagan field in the Caspian Sea said that it had struck oil in a second well, supporting estimates that Kashagan may be the largest find in 30 years. The new well yielded oil at 3,400 barrels a day and gas at 7.6 million cubic feet a day, according to ENI of Italy, the consortium member chosen to manage the field. Drilling work was interrupted last month by a minor oil spill. Birgit Brauer (NYT)

abstract: Travis Street Partners raises its hostile bid for Houston oil services company ICO Inc to about $70.3 million to top offer from company's management (S)
snippet: Travis Street Partners raises its hostile bid for Houston oil services company ICO Inc to about $70.3 million to top offer from company's management (S)
lead_paragraph: The investor group Travis Street Partners said yesterday that it had raised its hostile bid for the Houston oil services company ICO Inc. to about $70.3 million to top an offer from the company's management. Travis, a Houston-based partnership, had bid about $60 million in April and was outbid earlier this week by the management group, which is led by ICO's chairman, Al Packholder. The management group bid about $68 million, or $3 a share. The Travis group, which already owns about 5 percent of ICO's 22.7 million outstanding shares, bid $3.10 a share for the rest of ICO's stock.

abstract: Cross Timbers Oil Company budgets $250 million for oil and gas development in 2001 (S)
snippet: Cross Timbers Oil Company budgets $250 million for oil and gas development in 2001 (S)
lead_paragraph: The Cross Timbers Oil Company has budgeted $250 million for oil and gas development in 2001, according to the company's 2000 annual report. As it has done before, the company expects to finance the development program with cash flow from operations. About 50 percent of the development budget will be spent in East Texas, with the balance allocated among other properties. Exploration spending is expected to be about 4 percent of the 2001 budget. In 2000, Cross Timbers' cash expenditures for exploration and development totaled $155.4 million, compared with $91.6 million in 1999.

lead_paragraph: In a deal combining independent producers in Canada's oil patch, Anderson Exploration Ltd. agreed to buy Numac Oil Ltd. for 825 million Canadian dollars ($553 million) in cash, or 8 Canadian dollars a share, a 25 percent premium to Numac's closing price Wednesday. snippet: Halliburton Co agrees to acquire Petrobank, online information unit of Petroleum Geo-Services, Halliburton competitor based in Oslo, for $179 million (S)
lead_paragraph: The Halliburton Company, the oil field services company headed by Dick Cheney before he became the Republican nominee for vice president, has agreed to acquire Petrobank, an online information unit of Petroleum Geo-Services, a Halliburton competitor based in Oslo, for $179 million, the Norwegian company said in a statement. Petroleum Geo-Services has been selling peripheral businesses to raise cash and reduce debt, among them a 20 percent stake in the Spinnaker Exploration Company, sold last month for $150 million.
