abstract: WASHINGTON, April 9 — Retail gasoline prices jumped 5.8 cents in the last week, the biggest gain in 10 months, reaching a national average of $1.50 a gallon, according to a Department of Energy survey. The weekly gain was the biggest since mid-June and pushed prices above year-ago levels for the first time in six weeks. Prices were 2.5 cents higher than in the week a year ago, the survey of about 800 filling stations showed. Prices were the highest on the West Coast, where a gallon of regular rose 2.3 cents, to $1.66 a gallon, and in the Midwest, where gasoline rose 7.2 cents, to $1.52. Regular gasoline was the cheapest in the region from Alabama to New Mexico, where prices rose 5.9 cents, to $1.413 a gallon. Retail diesel fuel rose 0.6 cent, to $1.397 a gallon, the department said. Diesel prices are 2.2 cents lower than a year ago.

abstract: Enbridge Inc of Canada expands its oil and gas pipeline holdings in US with $350 million purchase of Midcoast Energy Resources Inc (S)
snippet: Enbridge Inc of Canada expands its oil and gas pipeline holdings in US with $350 million purchase of Midcoast Energy Resources Inc (S)
lead_paragraph: The Canadian oil and gas distributor Enbridge Inc. is expanding its pipeline holdings in the United States with the $350 million purchase of Midcoast Energy Resources Inc. of Houston. Midcoast's $250 million of debt will also be assumed by Enbridge. Based in Calgary, Alberta, Enbridge operates the main pipeline carrying oil from Alberta to markets in eastern Canada and the midwestern United States. It is also the largest distributor of natural gas in Canada. Midcoast has oil and gas pipeline systems in the Gulf Coast and the Midwest. Enbridge expects to complete the $27-a-share purchase this summer.

snippet: Two explosions on world's largest offshore oil platform, operated by Petrobras in Campos Basin about 78 miles off Brazilian coast, leave one worker dead and nine missing; Petrobras has suffered series of costly oil spills in recent months, and lab...
lead_paragraph: A pair of explosions before dawn yesterday on the world's largest offshore oil platform, operated by Petrobras in the Campos Basin about 78 miles off the Brazilian coast, left one worker dead and nine missing. Calling the situation ''grave,'' the president of Petrobras, Henri Phillipe Reichstuhl, said the 40-story platform, which produces 80,000 barrels of oil a day, was listing heavily and could capsize. Petrobras has suffered a series of costly oil spills in recent months, and labor unions say 81 workers have died in industrial accidents on Petrobras projects since 1998. Larry Rohter (NYT)

abstract: Editorial holds Pres Bush's long-awaited energy plan is unbalanced effort whose main objective seems to be to satisfy ambitions of oil, gas and coal industries, either by easing environmental rules or by opening public lands for aggressive exploration, while doing little for efficiency or renewable energy; says, on more fundamental level, that plan fails to make case that energy crisis even exists; says it will be up to an attentive Congress to ensure that some good ideas survive while bad ones disappear
snippet: Editorial holds Pres Bush's long-awaited energy plan is unbalanced effort whose main objective seems to be to satisfy ambitions of oil, gas and coal industries, either by easing environmental rules or by opening public lands for aggressive explora...
lead_paragraph: President Bush's long-awaited energy plan is as flawed and one-sided as its advance notices suggested it would be. Its 105 separate provisions include several potentially useful proposals aimed at improving energy efficiency and modernizing the country's power grid and pipelines. It also challenges Congress and the country to a long-overdue debate about nuclear power. But on the whole it is an alarmingly unbalanced piece of work whose main objective seems to be to satisfy the ambitions of the oil, gas and coal industries, either by easing environmental rules or by opening public lands for aggressive exploration.

abstract: Governments of Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan and Turkey sign memorandum of understanding that will allow Kazakhstan's growing oil industry to participate in 1,040-mile pipeline to be built from Baku, Azerbaijan, Ceyhan on Mediterranean coast of Turkey over next three years; analysts say agreement makes more viable proposed one-million-barrel-a-day pipeline, favored by US over other proposed routes through Russia or Iran; A Elizabeth Jones, senior US State Department officer, signs agreement as witness (S)
snippet: Governments of Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan and Turkey sign memorandum of understanding that will allow Kazakhstan's growing oil industry to participate in 1,040-mile pipeline to be built from Baku, Azerbaijan, Ceyhan on Mediterranean coast of ...
lead_paragraph: The governments of Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan and Turkey signed a memorandum of understanding that will allow Kazakhstan's growing oil industry to participate in a 1,040-mile pipeline to be built from Baku, Azerbaijan, to Ceyhan on the Mediterranean coast of Turkey over the next three years. Analysts said the agreement made more viable the proposed one-million-barrel-a-day pipeline, favored by the United States over other proposed routes through Russia or Iran. A senior United States State Department officer, A. Elizabeth Jones, signed the agreement as a witness.

lead_paragraph: The Anadarko Petroleum Corporation has agreed to buy the Berkley Petroleum Corporation of Calgary, Alberta, for 1.2 billion Canadian dollars ($777 million), or 11.40 Canadian dollars a share, topping by 9 percent a hostile bid by the Hunt Petroleum Corporation. Berkley will become part of Anadarko Canada, also based in Calgary. Jim Emme, president of the Canadian unit, said the deal ''accelerates our long-term strategy by about three years.'' Timothy Pritchard

lead_paragraph: Soaring gasoline prices have landed President Bush in the middle of a political storm, and to some extent he has only himself to blame. Mr. Bush did not cause gas prices to rise, any more than President Bill Clinton did when prices jumped above $2 a gallon last summer. As with Mr. Clinton, there is little he can do in the short term to bring prices down. However, he set himself up, but good, for the lashing he is getting from the Democrats.

snippet: Mexican lawmakers opposed to Pres Vicente Fox want to remove four businessmen from board of state-owned oil company Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, saying Fox's appointments violate Constitution; say private citizens cannot be members of Pemex's bo...
lead_paragraph: Mexican lawmakers opposed to President Vicente Fox want to remove four businessmen from the board of the state-owned oil company Petróleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, saying Mr. Fox's appointments violate the Constitution. ''Private citizens can't be members of Pemex's board as representatives of the state,'' said Carlos Aceves, a legislator from the centrist Institutional Revolutionary Party. Mr. Fox stunned the nation when he named the billionaire Carlos Slim Helú and three other top executives to the Pemex's board nine days ago.

abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column disputes Vice Pres Dick Cheney's intimation that high gas prices are result of shortage for which environmentalists are largely responsible; says conservation should be major element in our energy strategy, and that lack of conservation is large part of what we have been doing wrong; holds this year's gasoline price spike has nothing to do with a shortage of crude oil and binding constraint right now is nation's limited capacity to refine crude oil into gasoline; says what brought us up against this constraint was surge in demand as Americans responded to cheap gas of 1990's with renewed enthusiasm for gas-guzzling vehicles (M)
snippet: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column disputes Vice Pres Dick Cheney's intimation that high gas prices are result of shortage for which environmentalists are largely responsible; says conservation should be major element in our energy strategy, and that lack ...
lead_paragraph: Gasoline prices are rising again, and the administration is rushing to turn this into another argument for its drill-and-burn energy strategy. But a look at the causes of the current gasoline shortage actually suggests a quite different moral: namely, that conservation ought to be a major element in our energy strategy, and that lack of conservation is a large part of what we've been doing wrong.

abstract: Hunt Oil Co is running into stiffening resistance to its $694 million cash offer for Berkley Petroleum Corp of Calgary, Alberta; Berkley has adopted temporary 'poison pill' defense (S)
snippet: Hunt Oil Co is running into stiffening resistance to its $694 million cash offer for Berkley Petroleum Corp of Calgary, Alberta; Berkley has adopted temporary 'poison pill' defense (S)
lead_paragraph: The Hunt Oil Company is running into stiffening resistance to its $694 million cash offer for the Berkley Petroleum Corporation of Calgary, Alberta. The offer is Hunt's third takeover bid for a Canadian oil company in the last year. Berkley, which adopted a temporary ''poison pill'' defense, said it had succeeded in attracting the interest of other bidders, with whom it would share data next week. Hunt said its offer would remain open until Feb. 6, longer than the customary 21 days, to give Berkley time to sort through any competing offers. Expecting a bidding war, investors pushed Berkley's stock price above the 10 Canadian dollars a share bid by Hunt, which is privately held. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

abstract: RWE to spin off its chain of gasoline stations and refineries in Germany to new joint venture with Royal Dutch/Shell Group; new company will own 24 percent of gasoline stations in Germany (S)
snippet: RWE to spin off its chain of gasoline stations and refineries in Germany to new joint venture with Royal Dutch/Shell Group; new company will own 24 percent of gasoline stations in Germany (S)
lead_paragraph: Germany's biggest power company, RWE, said it would spin off its chain of gasoline stations and refineries in Germany to a new joint venture with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. The new company will own 24 percent of the gasoline stations in Germany and be the biggest operator in the country. The deal appears to set the stage for RWE to leave the gasoline business and focus on its central business of generating and distributing electrical power. It also allows Shell to strengthen both its refining capacity and its retail sales network. Edmund L. Andrews

abstract: ICO plans to sell its oilfield services business to Varco International for $165 million (S)
snippet: ICO plans to sell its oilfield services business to Varco International for $165 million (S)
lead_paragraph: ICO said yesterday that it planned to sell its oilfield services business to Varco International for $165 million to reduce debt and focus on petrochemical processing. ICO said it will use the proceeds to pay down its $118 million in public senior notes and retire its $32.3 million in convertible preferred stock. The actions will let ICO cut annual expenses by about $14.4 million in interest and dividends.

snippet: Barrett Resources Corp rejects $1.8 billion hostile takeover bid by Shell Oil Co, valued at $55-per-share, as inadequate (S)
lead_paragraph: The Barrett Resources Corporation said yesterday that its board voted unanimously to reject Shell Oil Company's $1.8 billion hostile bid. Barrett's chairman and chief executive, Peter A. Dea, reiterated his opposition to the $55-a-share bid from Shell, a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. ''The Shell offer is an inadequate attempt to buy Barrett at a price advantageous to Shell and not Barrett's shareholders.'' Mr. Dea said. Shares of Barrett ended yesterday higher than Shell's offer, at $61 a share, in anticipation of a bidding war. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

abstract: New Zealand court of appeals is expected to rule on whether shareholders of Fletcher Challenge Ltd can proceed with vote on $1.67 billion offer for company's energy assets from Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Apache Corp or must wait to consider rival offer from consortium led by Guinness Peat Group PLC (S)

lead_paragraph: A New Zealand court of appeals is expected to rule today on whether shareholders of Fletcher Challenge Ltd. can proceed with a vote on a $1.67 billion offer for the company's energy assets from the Royal/Dutch Shell Group and the Apache Corporation, or must wait to consider a rival offer from a consortium led by the Guinness Peat Group P.L.C. The rival offer, made through a company called Peak Petroleum, values the energy assets at as much as $3.85 a share, topping Shell's latest bid of $3.55 a share. Fletcher has raised questions about the consortium's ability to fund the bid, as well as the offers contingency on Peak Petroleum examining Fletcher's books. Suzanne Kapner

lead_paragraph: A group led by the investment company Guinness Peat Group said it planned to offer cash and shares worth $1.7 billion to buy Fletcher Energy, New Zealand's biggest oil company. The bid would top one made by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and, if successful, would be a blow to the expansion plans of Shell, which is trying to build its natural gas business in the Asia-Pacific region. The Guinness group, which includes the Greymouth Petroleum Mining Company, would pay at least $3.70 a share in cash, compared with Shell's $3.34.

Some 4.4 million southern Sudanese have been driven from their homes, the largest displaced population in the world. It is hard to imagine this war getting worse, but now it is -- thanks to the advent of lucrative oil exports.

abstract: Pure Resources Inc agrees to purchase Hallwood Energy Corp for $268 million in cash and assumed debt; purchase will increase Pure's natural gas output and add to its oil and gas reserves in Southwest (S)
snippet: Pure Resources Inc agrees to purchase Hallwood Energy Corp for $268 million in cash and assumed debt; purchase will increase Pure's natural gas output and add to its oil and gas reserves in Southwest (S)
lead_paragraph: Pure Resources Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Hallwood Energy Corporation for $268 million in cash and assumed debt to increase natural gas output. Hallwood, an oil and gas producer, put itself up for sale this month. Pure Resources will pay $12.50 for each Hallwood common share, 38 percent more than Hallwood's closing price Thursday. Pure Resources also will pay $10.84 for each preferred share and assume the debt of Hallwood, which is based in Denver. A Pure Resources spokesman, Jack Harper, declined to say how much of Hallwood's debt it would assume. Hallwood had $79.4 million in long-term debt in 2000, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The transaction brings Pure Resources more oil and gas producing fields in Texas and New Mexico, where it currently owns most of its properties.

lead_paragraph: The Norwegian government said it had chosen three investment banks to manage the initial public offering of Statoil, the state-owned oil company. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and UBS Warburg, the investment-banking arm of UBS A.G., will coordinate the offering internationally along with DnB Markets, a unit of Den Norske Bank, a Norwegian bank. Goldman Sachs, which managed the initial offering of Telenor, Norway's dominant telephone company, late last year, was notably omitted from the deal. The Statoil offering is expected to raise 3 billion to 5 billion euros ($2.9 billion to $4.8 billion) for 10 percent to 25 percent of the big oil company.

snippet: BP Amoco excludes from its annual meeting shareholder resolution asking company to reconsider drilling in Arctic National Wildlife Refuge of Alaska (S)
lead_paragraph: BP Amoco has excluded from its April 19 annual meeting a resolution asking the company to reconsider drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge of Alaska. The resolution was sponsored by a group of American and British investors, some of whom hold their shares in the form of depository receipts. BP Amoco rebuffed a similar move a few weeks ago, arguing that foreign investors who hold their stock in the form of depository receipts could not initiate shareholder resolutions. The shareholders resubmitted the resolution March 8, believing they had recruited the required amount of registered holders of common stock. But a BP Amoco spokeswoman said the group did not meet its guidelines. Suzanne Kapner

abstract: BP Amoco will sell its 7 percent stake in Russia's largest oil company, Lukoil Holding and use $650 million in proceeds to invest in projects elsewhere (S)
snippet: BP Amoco will sell its 7 percent stake in Russia's largest oil company, Lukoil Holding and use $650 million in proceeds to invest in projects elsewhere (S)
lead_paragraph: The largest foreign investor in Russia, BP Amoco, said it would sell its 7 percent stake in Russia's largest oil company, Lukoil Holding. BP Amoco, which also owns a chain of gas stations and an interest in a natural gas field, said the stake was not big enough to give it influence over Lukoil's management. The company, which acquired the stake in its takeover of the Atlantic Richfield Company last year, said it would use the $650 million in proceeds to invest in projects elsewhere. BP Amoco has been struggling for about two years to rescue its $484 million investment in another Russian oil producer, Sidanco. Stephanie Tavernise (NYT)

lead_paragraph: Shares of Friede Goldman Halter rose 34 percent yesterday after the company, which builds offshore drilling equipment, said it had resolved a two-year dispute with the Norwegian driller Ocean Rig. Friede Goldman's shares rose 84 cents, to $3.29, a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Ocean Rig, based in Oslo, said it would pay Friede Goldman to finish building two offshore rigs. Friede Goldman said on March 1 that it had stopped work on two Ocean deepwater rigs because it wanted to be paid more.

abstract: Sen Ron Wyden writes Pres Clinton asking that ban on exports of Alaskan crude oil, lifted in 1996, be reinstated; newspaper Oregonian reported on Jan 7 that BP Amoco sold Alaskan crude in Asia at lower prices than it could have received from American refiners to squeeze supply in California, Oregon and Washington, where gasoline prices are as much as 20 percent higher than national average (S)
snippet: Sen Ron Wyden writes Pres Clinton asking that ban on exports of Alaskan crude oil, lifted in 1996, be reinstated; newspaper Oregonian reported on Jan 7 that BP Amoco sold Alaskan crude in Asia at lower prices than it could have received from Ameri...
lead_paragraph: After an Oregon newspaper reported on Sunday that BP Amoco had manipulated crude oil prices on the West Coast, Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, wrote to President Clinton asking that a ban on exports of Alaskan crude oil, lifted in 1996, be reinstated. The Oregonian of Portland said that BP Amoco had sold Alaskan crude in Asia at lower prices than it could have received from American refiners to squeeze supply in California, Oregon and Washington, where gasoline prices are as much as 20 percent higher than the national average. The newspaper said it obtained the documents by suing the Federal Trade Commission, which reviewed BP Amoco's takeover of Atlantic Richfield in 1999. A spokeswoman for BP Amoco said the company had done nothing illegal or anticompetitive.

abstract: Editorial backs opposition by Florida Gov Jeb Bush to President George W Bush administration plan to open area off Florida's coast in Gulf of Mexico to oil and gas exploration (S)
snippet: Editorial backs opposition by Florida Gov Jeb Bush to President George W Bush administration plan to open area off Florida's coast in Gulf of Mexico to oil and gas exploration (S)
lead_paragraph: One of President Bush's more vexing problems is figuring out how to satisfy the nation's growing appetite for energy, especially natural gas, without damaging the environment. Just how vexing that problem is became clearer when news leaked out recently that the president's brother, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, strongly opposes the administration's plan to open up an area off the Florida coast in the Gulf of Mexico to oil and gas exploration. The polls have been telling President Bush that the public favors conservation over development, even when energy supplies are short. His brother is now conveying essentially the same message.

abstract: Texas Attorney Gen John Cornyn says state has sued Exxon Mobil for 'tens of millions of dollars' for extracting oil and natural gas from state without authorization; suit says company, which obtained permission from state in 1970's to drill on parcel of land called Hawkins Field on Wood County, Tex, strayed onto adjacent state-owned land not covered by permits (S)
snippet: Texas Attorney Gen John Cornyn says state has sued Exxon Mobil for 'tens of millions of dollars' for extracting oil and natural gas from state without authorization; suit says company, which obtained permission from state in 1970's to drill on par...
lead_paragraph: The Texas attorney general, John Cornyn, said yesterday that the state had sued Exxon Mobil for ''tens of millions of dollars'' for extracting oil and natural gas from state land without authorization. The suit, filed in United States District Court in Houston, said the company, which obtained permission from the state in the 1970's to drill on a parcel of land called Hawkins Field in Wood County in eastern Texas, had strayed onto adjacent state-owned land not covered by its permits. Exxon Mobil spokesmen could not be reached immediately for comment. In December, an Alabama jury ordered Exxon Mobil to pay $3.5 billion in damages after it found the company guilty of defrauding the state of royalties owed on natural gas from wells in state waters; the company is appealing the verdict.

abstract: Texaco Inc says its company headquarters in Harrison, NY, will be closed when acquisition by Chevron Corp is completed; headquarters of merged company will be in San Francisco; combined work force will be reduced by seven percent overall, or about 4,000 employees (S)
snippet: Texaco Inc says its company headquarters in Harrison, NY, will be closed when acquisition by Chevron Corp is completed; headquarters of merged company will be in San Francisco; combined work force will be reduced by seven percent overall, or about...
lead_paragraph: Since October, when Texaco, the oil company headquartered in Harrison, N.Y., announced that it had agreed to be acquired by Chevron Corporation and that the new headquarters would be in San Francisco, it had been assumed that the corporate presence in Westchester County would shrink, but it was not clear by how much. This week, Texaco, one of the county's largest employers and a philanthropic powerhouse, confirmed people's worst fears: no one will stay behind if the takeover goes through. In a presentation on Tuesday at Texaco's corporate center, managers said the 1,000 people working there could apply for positions in the newly merged company, to be called ChevronTexaco Corporation, at a number of places in the United States, or could seek severance packages. Over all, the combined work force will be reduced by 7 percent, or about 4,000 employees, said Paul Weeditz, a Texaco spokesman. Lisa W. Foderaro

lead_paragraph: Although President Bush has spoken sourly of his predecessor's enthusiasm for trying to solve foreign conflicts, he met recently with the leaders of Armenia and Azerbaijan, two nations locked in a seemingly intractable ethnic dispute. Mr. Bush's involvement in negotiations over Nagorno-Karabakh -- an ethnic Armenian enclave inside Azerbaijan -- is undoubtedly in part due to the extensive oil and gas reserves in the Caspian region. Nevertheless, it is a welcome move, which we hope signals that Washington will remain engaged with troubled regions of the globe.

abstract: EUROPE TURKEY: PLAN ENCOURAGES MARKETS Tur- key's currency, stocks and bonds rose on expectations that a government economic program announced over the weekend would win financial support from international lenders. The lira gained 2.6 percent; the benchmark stock index rose 4.9 percent; and the yield on the three-month bill maturing Aug. 8 fell 7 percentage points, to 131 percent. On Saturday, the economy minister, Kemal Dervis, announced the country's plans for ending an economic crisis that has dragged on for about two months. Turkish officials expect to complete talks with the International Monetary Fund and other lenders this week.   (Bloomberg News)

abstract: Editorial laments most recent threat to remote and unspoiled Galapagos Islands, oil spill created by Ecuadorean tanker

lead_paragraph: The Galápagos Islands have belonged to Ecuador since 1832, just before Charles Darwin arrived on board the Beagle in 1835. Remote and biologically unspoiled as they were even then, the Galápagos were nonetheless already part of the larger world, a regular port of call. While it was true that on those reptilian islands ''the chief sound of life is a hiss,'' as Melville wrote, it was also true, according to Darwin's biographer, Janet Browne, that you could buy pigs and goats there or mail a letter. But the isolation that made the islands a perfect laboratory in which to study the variation of species as they occur in nature remained largely unviolated.

abstract: Oil prices have plummeted to their lowest levels in two years, gasoline is sure to follow, and the unlikely party responsible for what could be a boost to the weak economy is the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries. Don't chalk it up to altruism. OPEC has declared a price war, telling rivals that it will not try to prop up prices by cutting production unless they follow suit. So far, OPEC's competitors, in particular Russia, refuse to cooperate.   Neela Banerjee

abstract: Article in series, The Census, describes shrinking town of Morland, Kan, whose population is now 164, down from 234 in 1990; Morland sits in path of decline that 2000 census finds sweeping through small towns of Great Plains; even as nation's population grew 13 percent in 1990's, Census Bureau has found that 676 of nation's 3,141 counties lost people; most of decline is in wheat, ranching and oil country in Texas, Oklahoma, Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas, Minnesota and Dakotas; Graham County, which includes Morland, has lost 17 percent of its population in last decade; within 50 miles of Morland, fading towns lost 15 percent to 30 percent of their inhabitants; communities throughout Great Plains have been losing people for nearly century; in Morland, decline was brought on by mechanization of agriculture and nearly two decades of low wheat prices and shrinking oil fields; staples of community have fallen away one by one as businesses close; hardest loss will come this week, when Morland High graduates its last class and closes its doors; photo; map; graph (L)

abstract: Editorial opposes Pres Bush's call for opening coastal plain of Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration and urges Congress to insist on comprehensive energy strategy that emphasizes conservation as well as exploration (M)
snippet: Editorial opposes Pres Bush's call for opening coastal plain of Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration and urges Congress to insist on comprehensive energy strategy that emphasizes conservation as well as exploration (M)
lead_paragraph: In his opening days in office, President Bush has taken on a number of issues such as taxes and education with discipline and an appearance of growing confidence. Perhaps for that reason he believes that California's energy crisis has given him the hot hand for rolling back environmental standards and pressing his shortsighted campaign to open the 1.5-million-acre coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration. It hardly signals a balanced approach to put Vice President Dick Cheney, also an oil man, in charge of a task force aimed at developing an energy strategy to reduce America's ''reliance on foreign oil'' and ''bring more energy into the marketplace.'' Mr. Bush made clear that legislation asking Congress to open the refuge would be an essential component of that strategy.

snippet: Editorial says bill proposed by Sen Frank Murkowski to overhaul nation's energy policies fails to balance responsible development with energy conservation; says it is essentially an oil driller's bill, despite nods toward energy efficiency; says d...
lead_paragraph: Give Senator Frank Murkowski this much. He has offered the first major bill in a decade aimed at overhauling the country's energy policies. But the Alaska Republican's 300-page measure is not by any stretch a blueprint for a measured policy that balances responsible development with energy conservation. Despite some nods toward energy efficiency, it is essentially an oil driller's bill. The larger danger is that it could serve as a template for the cabinet-level task force appointed by President Bush to devise a comprehensive national energy strategy. That panel, which is led by Vice President Dick Cheney, an oilman himself, is already disposed to honor Mr. Bush's campaign pledge to sweep away regulatory impediments to new exploration. If the panel endorses Mr. Murkowski's approach, environmentalists and their Congressional allies should be ready for a protracted and difficult struggle on Capitol Hill.

lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, in one of his first statements about the California energy crisis, George W. Bush placed the blame squarely on pollution controls: ''If there's any environmental regulations preventing California from having a 100 percent max output at their plants -- as I understand may be -- then we need to relax those standards.'' But his assertion was swiftly contradicted -- not just by environmentalists and California officials, but by the energy industry. A spokesman for Houston-based Reliant Energy, which operates four Southern California plants, told The Los Angeles Times that assertions that environmental regulations were holding back power production were ''absolutely false.''

abstract: At least half of the country's 152 oil refineries are believed to be violating air-pollution laws, federal officials say, but with the refineries stretched near capacity, the Bush administration is debating how hard to crack down.    Refinery capacity, Vice President Dick Cheney has said, is among the issues at the center of the country's energy problems and has been a major factor in the recent surge in gasoline prices. The report released on Thursday by Mr. Cheney's energy task force orders the Environmental Protection Agency and the Justice Department to review their enforcement of the pollution laws in light of the potential to discourage refinery expansion.

abstract: Editorial asserts that Interior secretary nominee Gale Norton has used confirmation hearings to smoothly present herself as naturalist and conservationist, different from her image as 'right-wing political figure' that often in past took stands against environment; regrets that she did not budge from commitment to help open Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil exploration
snippet: Editorial asserts that Interior secretary nominee Gale Norton has used confirmation hearings to smoothly present herself as naturalist and conservationist, different from her image as 'right-wing political figure' that often in past took stands ag...
lead_paragraph: It will be interesting to see what kind of interior secretary Gale Norton turns out to be. Given her right-wing political pedigree, Democrats, moderate Republicans and environmentalists had every reason to fear that George W. Bush was handing them another James Watt, Ronald Reagan's disastrous interior secretary and one of Ms. Norton's early mentors. Yet at her confirmation hearings this week Ms. Norton smoothly presented herself as a naturalist and conservationist, redefining some of her earlier positions and softening others. Regrettably, she did not budge from her commitment to help Mr. Bush open up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil exploration. But her basic message was that she would serve all Americans, and not just the property-rights crowd that has been assiduously promoting her cause.

abstract: OPEC's problems could translate into substantial benefits for American business and consumers.    With oil prices falling as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries fails to reach agreement with Russia and other oil producers outside the cartel, the United States is poised to receive a much needed lift from lower energy costs, analysts said. That relief, together with lower interest rates, is expected to improve the odds that the economy will emerge from its downturn sooner rather than later.

abstract: Phillips Plans to Buy Tosco In $7 Billion Stock Deal  Phillips Petroleum agreed to acquire Tosco for $7 billion in stock, a deal that would make Phillips the nation's second-largest oil refiner. The transaction was approved by the boards of both companies.    The deal would create the fifth-largest gasoline retailer in the United States with more than 12,000 stations. Phillips is offering 0.8 share, or $46.50, for each Tosco share, a 34 percent premium. [National Report, Section A.]

lead_paragraph: A front-page article on Monday about the impact of falling fuel prices on the Bush administration's energy plan misstated comments by Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham about gasoline prices. Mr. Abraham testified to Congress that news reports about inflated prices could become a ''self-fulfilling prophecy'' and raise prices to $3 a gallon in the summer, but he did not warn that prices could go that high, and he said his information did not support predictions of so steep an increase.

abstract: The energy industry is drilling for natural gas, building gas pipelines and constructing power plants at an unprecedented pace as companies respond to high energy prices by significantly increasing investment.    The intense activity comes as President Bush prepares to unveil a national strategy to address what he has called an energy crisis. The policy is expected to emphasize streamlining of regulations, many of them intended to protect the environment, that Bush administration officials say have caused an alarming gap in energy supplies.

lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about drilling for oil and gas under the Great Lakes misstated a part of the Bush administration's plan for energy exploration. The administration is not ''calling for increased domestic drilling everywhere.'' Its recent energy plan calls for the Interior Department to identify suitable public lands for new oil and gas exploration. Drilling in the Great Lakes is not a part of the plan.

abstract: The air in the New York region is not what it used to be, and for the most part that's a good thing. Over the 30 years since the passage of the federal Clean Air Act, pollutants like lead, carbon monoxide and especially the gritty black soot that was long one of the region's most hallowed, if hated, symbols, have all sharply declined. The number of days each summer with the most severe ozone smog is typically no more than a third of what it was in the early 1980's.    At the same time, it became a lot easier to shift the blame elsewhere for the problems that did remain. The industrial Midwest, with its coal-burning factories and power plants, all wafting their toxic fumes east on the prevailing upper air currents, became a handy shorthand for the idea that poor little New York was the victim of someone else's excess.
lead_paragraph: The air in the New York region is not what it used to be, and for the most part that's a good thing. Over the 30 years since the passage of the federal Clean Air Act, pollutants like lead, carbon monoxide and especially the gritty black soot that was long one of the region's most hallowed, if hated, symbols, have all sharply declined. The number of days each summer with the most severe ozone smog is typically no more than a third of what it was in the early 1980's.

abstract: INTERNATIONAL   A3-12    Envoys Discuss Peace For Russia and Chechnya  Top envoys from the Kremlin and the Chechen rebel government met publicly in Moscow to discuss peace for the first time since war erupted 27 months ago between Russia and Chechnya, a separatist province. Both officials, Akhmed Zakayev, the deputy prime minister of Chechnya, and Viktor G. Kazantsev, above, a representative of President Vladimir V. Putin, were reported to have said that the talks were productive and that they would continue.   A10    Sharon Won't Budge on Talks  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel, concerned about possible new pressure by the Bush administration to accelerate steps toward peace negotiations, rejected the idea of easing a requirement that seven days of quiet must precede other formal steps endorsed by both sides. News media have reported that Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will request that Mr. Sharon drop the condition in a speech scheduled for today.   A10

abstract: In an administration dominated by oilmen and deregulators, Christie Todd Whitman is shading things as green as she can
snippet: In an administration dominated by oilmen and deregulators, Christie Todd Whitman is shading things as green as she can
lead_paragraph: Christie Whitman arrives at the home ballpark of the Lowell Spinners, the Boston Red Sox' Class-A affiliate in the old mill town of Lowell, Mass. The stadium rises atop a cleaned-up toxic-waste site and is the kind of place administrators of the Environmental Protection Agency go. It's a glinting citadel of the new and well made, wedged among boarded-up factories. But there is no crowd waiting, only a few baseball staff members. When she was governor of New Jersey, Whitman caused a stir wherever she went; many expected her to ascend either to the United States Senate or to the vice-presidential slot on the 2000 Republican ticket. Instead she now visits toxic-waste sites. ''At least today is a clean day,'' Whitman notes. Often when she travels to inspect something, it's garbage or ooze or worse.

abstract: Laura Pierce letter on Mary Rogan's Mar 4 article urges efforts to aid both Innu children and their parents
snippet: Laura Pierce letter on Mary Rogan's Mar 4 article urges efforts to aid both Innu children and their parents
lead_paragraph: The plight of the Innu community is a bizarre generational tragedy (Mary Rogan, March 4). Rescue and relocation of the Innu children, while drastic, seems courageous and humane. It is a strange testament to the resourcefulness of these young people that with no access to hard drugs, they drugged themselves with gasoline from snowmobiles to blur their world.
